author: defipunk
content:
Only semi-related, but
(a) How expensive is it to scan for SLOADs for new TX vs simply executing them? My gut feeling would be that unless there is a "static" flag on the TX, there is no way to figure this out without executing the TX itself?
(b) As an alternative:  I haven't looked at Solana in all that much detail, but afaik they use an optimistic concurrency approach to parallelize their TX execution. I think it's an interesting idea, but having seen the effects of large launches, I wonder if specifically crafting collisions isn't a huge attack vector for them?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
I thought a bit more about that after your last post.
The problem is that most transactions are non static.
If you code in solidity you know that there are three classes of functions: public, view and pure. 
Only pure functions can be parallelized (and view that only look at the block parameters).
Pure functions can be called without sending a transaction on your local node though, which means there are almost no static transactions out there.
